Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: A client quietly shares a private concern while filling out forms at the check-in table.
Story: I was at the community center, volunteering at the check-in table, when my younger sister, Mia, arrived unexpectedly. She waved, excited to see me, and I felt a warm rush of affection. We’d promised to include each other in more of our lives, and I’d invited her to join me after my shift so we could hang out. As I helped a client fill out forms, she leaned in and quietly shared a personal concern about her living situation, trusting me to keep it private. Just then, Mia came over, curious about what I was doing and eager to chat. She asked who I was talking to and what was going on, wanting to be part of my world. I could see the hope in her eyes—she wanted to feel included, to share in my experiences. But the client’s words echoed in my mind, and I knew I couldn’t betray her trust. My heart pounded as I stood between my sister’s expectation of openness and the client’s need for confidentiality, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
